reviewText: This is the story of the Roman soldier who was on guard at the Tomb of Jesus Christ.  He had also participated in the execution of this Jewish rebel, and when the Jewish leaders bribed the other soldiers to say that Jesus' followers had stolen Jesus' body while the guards slept, this soldier wanted to know what really happened.  Of course, this question is NOT what the Jews or the centurion want to be answered. The story is is very interesting, entertaining, and moving.The down side is that the production suffers from really crappy plastic and vinyl Roman armor, improper Roman equipment and a lack of understanding about what soldiers actually were stationed in Judea, which makes me cringe when I see so many correctable anachronisms in an otherwise excellent presentataion!This is a great film to use when witnessing to your youth group!
summary: The Motion Picture of the Book by Max Lucado

reviewText: Easter videos usually feature lots of pastel flowers, delicate sunrises and everyone standing around looking Apostolic.  This is not one of those videos: everything is sun-baked with not a flower in sight and the sweaty faces are registering anger, pain, fear and hatred as much as spiritual epiphany.  Based on a short story by Max Lucado.  This is the Bible by way of John Frankenheimer rather than de Mille.A Roman solider, new to the occupation of Judea, unexpectedly pulls duty guarding Christ's crucifixion and later His tomb Saturday night.  He is having nightmares about both, and he is  not quite sure what he remembers about that fateful night.  He is determined to find out, despite opposition from both the Roman legion and the Jewish collaborators.  The answers he finds will change his life.The video runs about an hour.  It is not a kiddy video or a straightfoward depiction of the gospel story.  This is a drama told by one of the protagonists on the "edge" of the story.  There is some violence.  Menace and torture are implied (other than the crucifixion, which is dealt with in brief, graphic flashbacks).Although a complete work of fiction.  I think it depicts well the highly charged atmosphere of Jerusalem in the days following the Resurrection.  It credibly shows an experience that at least some early disciples of Christ would recognize, and offers one explanation for why the Gospels know about the events Saturday at the tomb.  If the movie has any faults it is not always clear in showing why some of the chracters are doing what they are doing.  I don't know whether to blame the script or the acting.This is not existential like "Barrabas;" blasphemous like "The Last Temptation of Christ," or conventional like "The Greatest Story Ever Told."  It more like "Ben-Hur" with psychological insight.
summary: An edgey look at the Resurrection
